awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  4D Flightpath-Based Autonomous Separation Assurance Systems (ASAS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable the safe and autonomous management and control of airspace. The Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) and Advanced Air Mobility (AAM) sectors are expected to grow but that will only be economically viable if the UAV and AAM operations are highly automated. The technology developed in this project uses a new trajectory-based approach to aircraft and airspace operations to support that level of automation. The immediate focus of the project is on the emerging AAM aircraft and airspace, but the technology has an even broader potential impact for application to the commercial Air Traffic Control (ATC) system. In the United States, over a period of one year, over 1800 operational errors (breaches of minimum required separation) were officially attributed to airspace controller error. The commercial ATC is largely a manual system and and there is a limit to the number of flights air traffic controllers can manage with incremental improvements of the present system. Expansions in the number of airborne vehicles (of all sorts) requires that air traffic control systems be more automated to maintain their safety record. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to produce a functioning proof-of-concept demonstration of an autonomous aircraft and airspace management and control system for AAM class vehicles. These aviation sectors are expected to see a rapid expansion but the highly manual implementation of airspace control will not be practical or economically viable. The objective of this research is to support a much higher level of automation, enabling the growth of the sectors. Aircraft missions are defined by 4D analytic flightpath models; Aircraft are must precisely follow the flightpaths set by the models. Deterministic and certain algorithms autonomously detect and resolve potential loss of separation events between flightpath models of all aircraft in the airspace. The autopilots allow the aircraft to operate autonomously and the deconfliction ensures safe operation of the airspace. Development of the proposed demonstration system will identify and resolve communication and integration issues. The demonstration system seeks to provide a test case to evaluate the viability, scalability, and robustness of the technology and to explore the responses to nonstandard and unforeseen operating conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The technology developed in the 4D Avionic Systems NSF SBIR Phase I project (grant number 2111827) is a novel knowledge model-based approach to development and deployment of aircraft and airspace management and control services. The approach is demonstrated in an autonomous aircraft loss of separation conflict detection and resolution system. The knowledge-based system acquires, stores, reasons, decides, and acts based on knowledge models. Perhaps the greatest insight gained during the project was how important the forms of the knowledge models are to the cognitive functions of the system and the ability to use (act on) the knowledge in meaningful ways. The form of the FlightPath model is of particular importance because it is used in so many ways across the different processes of the system. The form of the geodetic AirSpace Sectors model is important because it is the means by which the system is scaled to the global airspace and to multiple airspace domains. The system is based on a set of analytic models that encapsulate knowledge about the airspace and the aircraft and obstacles in it and a set of cognitive processes (algorithms) that operate on the knowledge in the models to produce additional knowledge and actionable intelligence to control the operation of the aircraft in the airspace. The system is expandable by introducing additional knowledge models and processes, accommodating new sensors and knowledge sources, and providing additional operational functionality of the aircraft. The models and processes are integrated in a distributed relational knowledge server and in client agents. Client agents represent aircraft and obstacles in the air space and for 4D equipped aircraft reside onboard the aircraft.  

In the Phase I project there were four primary research and development outcomes to validate and demonstrate the technology. They were:

  1. demonstrate and validate the 4D autopilot operation (Flight Control System) in fixed-wing and multirotor Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles,
  2. demonstrate and validate the 4D FlightPath and Conflict Detection and Resolution algorithms in a scalable multi-vehicle simulation,
  3. demonstrate and validate the 4D Flight Management System by implementing the Conflict Detection & Resolution algorithms in the airborne computers of the Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles, and
  4. implement the Data Repository and Dissemination System and high-speed data communication links to both the Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles and the simulation to demonstrate the operation and explore the scalability and robustness of the Autonomous Separation Assurance System.

The means of validating and demonstrating the technology was a functioning prototype system incorporating the four outcomes. The prototype system was to include both real and simulated Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles operating autonomously in the airspace.

The 4D FlightPath model is able to define a complete mission of an Uncrewed Aerial Vehicle from preflight clearance to postflight documentation and the Flight Management System is able to execute the mission without human intervention. To test the system, missions were developed for two custom built (4D equipped) quadcopters flying aggressive straight and curved segment FlightPath models that intersected with six Loss of Separation conflict events. The FlightPath models of the missions, defined in a global coordinate system, were loaded into the two quadcopters, and they were located at their respective starting points. The system was initiated. The on-board Flight Management Systems performed their AirSpace Sectors Visited algorithms and shared their flight plan data with the Data Repository and Dissemination System. The Data Repository and Dissemination System performed the Cohort algorithms and exchanged the mission data with the cohort aircraft Flight Management Systems. The Flight Management Systems performed the Conflict Detection and Resolution algorithms and reported their resolved FlightPath models to the Data Repository and Dissemination System which issued a clear to fly notification back to the Flight Management Systems. The Flight Management Systems executed the deconflicted FlightPaths to complete their missions and returned to their starting location. The entire process was completed autonomously.

The Loss of Separation Event models provide complete observability of the conflict event and provide data for eight autonomous optimal resolution maneuver designs. The resolution maneuvers can be applied to either aircraft or shared between the aircraft in any proportion. The selection of the resolution maneuver is based on optimizing the operation of the airspace.

The FlightPath model and the 4D autopilot model support Trajectory Based Operations and provide a high degree of mission and airspace automation and reduce the dependence on manual deconfliction. The models also provide continuous compliance monitoring for the individual flights. The dynamic displays enabled by the models provide a high level of airspace situational awareness and management as well as operator control of mission execution.

The distributed knowledge repository and dissemination model localizes the global airspace and distributes the knowledge model data in addition to the communication and computational burdens.
